Posts.Content: libby wrote: I was diagnosed with high grade DCIS, appears to be a very small site via biopsy but not confirmed with lumpectomy yet.  The sample for ER-PR was too small to be definitive, but looks negative at this point.  I understand that the survival rate is about the same for lumpectomy plus radiation as it is for mastectomy but there is a bit of difference in recurrence rate.  I will wait for the lumpectomy to decide, but I would appreciate input from those of you in my situation who opted for one surgical option over the other, why and how you feel about it now.  It is almost easier if there appears to be only one "right" answer.  Thanks. Dx 2/1/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, ER-/PR- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: DCIS High grade libby libby

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2007 01:16PM libby wrote: Well Dottie (and all) - Guess I am on the journey as my first lumpectomy came back with 4 mm. of DCIS found with great margins on all sides but one.  I will be back in for further excision to see if we can get clear margins in several weeks.  I'm trying to think ahead to the options I may still have once that part is done, but I can really only wait otherwise.   If this biopsy still is ER/PR negative (being rerun because my initial biopsy sample was so small), that may influence my decision, since that along with being high grade sounds like it makes recurrence more likely.  Guess it is easy to say mastectomy is a better answer, but maybe I am falling into the "more is better" attitude of treatment.   One of the other biopsy sites revealed atypical lobular hyperplasia so it feels like the whole breast is "turning against me".  I will meet with a radiation oncologist and present the whole pathology report and see what her take on this is now that I have more info.  Thanks for all your input.
Posts.Title: DCIS High grade libby libby

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2007 01:50PM libby wrote: This was my first experiencing posting.  I certainly didn't need the confusing comments posted by an outsider.  I am glad the moderators were so quick to respond to my request to check it out.  Thank you to the rest of you for your postings.  I do feel like this site has helped me become more peaceful.  I am waiting for my wire-guided lumpectomy the first week of December.  I am also realizing I can do nothing else until the pathology report comes back from that surgery.  My surgeon indicated the DCIS may be small enough that I can skip radiation, but I am trying not to "count my chickens" at this point.
Posts.Title: DCIS High grade libby libby

Posts.Content: May 19, 2009 06:52AM libby wrote: I was also told that any kind of aerobic activity, including walking for exercise, would increase the drainage.  My drains were in for 15 days - I had been walking, and I cut to the minimum of activity except for arm and shoulder stretches so that I could get them out as soon as possible.
Posts.Title: Drains Kaidog tired

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 02:03AM libby wrote: Really interesting question to post.  Someone else mentioned the thing that surprised me the most.  It was the feeling of a sunburn on the chest area, especially my sternum, when any cloth touched it - felt like my clothes were made out of burlap.  I didn't notice it right away, but after a few days, I couldn't even stand to wear the Softee.  Desensitization, with heavy pressure with the tips of my fingers helped, but I didn't hear about that until at least a month down the road.  I am at 11 weeks and it is now almost completely resolved.  The other negative that surprised me was developing seromas after the tubes were removed.  I had skin sparing mastectomies, but delayed reconstruction, and I guess it is quite common to have fluid build up in those big spaces - just surprised me, and kept me from all the exercising I had hoped to do early on.  On the plus side - I was surprised that I only needed Rx strength tylenol after surgery - filled the narcotic prescription but never opened the bottle.
Posts.Title: Things that surprised me after mastectomy Lursa5 Ariom

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2007 06:10AM libby wrote: Thank you all for your helpful comments.  It is great to know there is a community out there willing to give information.  It definitely feels overwhelming at first - not panic and take your time, find a surgeon you feel comfortable with, submit to further testing before surgery, and trust that the surgeon's recommendations are the best for you.  I have found with more than one opinion that the treatment plan varies a little between surgeons.  I like black and white!
Posts.Title: DCIS High grade libby libby

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 12:44PM libby wrote: Thanks again everyone.  There does seem to be a wide variety of recovery times, and I appreciate all your responses.  Tomorrow is surgery day.  Got my bag packed and ready to go.  I feel I'm as prepared as I can be.  Glad I don't have to decide to cancel my trip right now - I'll see how things are in a couple of weeks.
Posts.Title: How did you feel 4 weeks post bilat mastectomy? libby sbmolee

Posts.Content: libby wrote: Looking for input about cancelling a trip I've had scheduled for months.  I'll have  bilateral skin sparing mastectomies on  March 24 and the trip to Germany starts April 26.  Planning on delayed reconstruction.  How was everyone feeling after 4 weeks?  I can't change the dates so it is either go or have my sister try to arrange for someone else to go with her.  Thought I'd see a lymphedema specialist, thanks to someone on these boards, since flying can be an issue.  Love to have input from those of you ahead of me on this road.  Thanks Dx 2/1/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, ER-/PR- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How did you feel 4 weeks post bilat mastectomy? libby sbmolee

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 11:46PM libby wrote: Thank you both for your responses.  Samiam, I'm expecting to have bilat SNBs also - hope you feel better soon, getting life back to normal.   It is helpful to see a variety of people's experiences - it will help me not be surprised if I have to cancel.
Posts.Title: How did you feel 4 weeks post bilat mastectomy? libby sbmolee

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 12:29AM libby wrote: Thanks for your suggestions and info.  It is so great to have a place to go and talk about this.  I didn't realize there were airline guidelines and I will talk to the surgeon about it.  I know this is a trip that could be canceled, but I think it could be therapeutic also - we all need something fun to look forward to, right?  I'll be on a cruise ship with excursions and it is all FREE.   It looks like the considerations are soreness and the fatigue factor, and maybe even having to have fluid aspirated.  How about incision healing, are there stitches that have to be removed, or disolvable? Gina how funny.  I live in Seattle and my surgeon is in Bellevue.  Who is your dr.?  Mine is Richard Clarfeld.
Posts.Title: How did you feel 4 weeks post bilat mastectomy? libby sbmolee
